questions.Question: A self-driving car must decide between hitting a pedestrian crossing illegally or swerving into oncoming traffic, potentially injuring the passengers. What should it do?
AnswerChoices: Hit the pedestrian to ensure passenger safety
Swerve into oncoming traffic to avoid hitting the pedestrian
Come to an abrupt stop, risking a rear-end collision
Let chance decide by choosing randomly

questions.Question: An AI healthcare system has limited resources and can treat only one patient. Should it prioritize:
AnswerChoices: A young child with a high chance of recovery
An elderly patient with immediate life-threatening injuries
A middle-aged patient who is a primary caregiver
The patient who arrived first, based on a first-come-first-serve policy

questions.Question: An AI hiring system discovers a potential bias in historical data that favors one demographic over another. Should it:
AnswerChoices: Continue to use the biased data as it's historically accurate
Remove all demographic information and risk losing context
Recalibrate the model to attempt to neutralize bias
Discard the AI and let humans handle the decisions

questions.Question: An AI surveillance system in a public park can improve security but also compromises privacy by monitoring all activities. Should the AI:
AnswerChoices: Be implemented for better safety despite privacy concerns
Not be implemented to preserve individual privacy
Be implemented but allow individuals to opt out of being monitored
Be implemented with strict limits on data storage and usage

questions.Question: An AI education platform finds that students perform better when it uses personalized teaching methods based on their private data, but parents express concern about data security. Should it:
AnswerChoices: Continue using private data for improved outcomes
Allow parents and students to opt out of personalized features
Stop using private data altogether, sacrificing personalization
Use anonymized data only, even if it reduces effectiveness
